Election 2020

A detailed look at how Klobuchar's surge affected the New Hampshire primary

By Jeff Hargarten
and Torey Van Oot
Star Tribune February 12, 2020

After a middling performance in the chaotic Iowa caucuses, Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar headed into New Hampshire's primary with some polling momentum amid growing uncertainty among the Democratic presidential nomination field.

Klobuchar, who along with South Bend, Ind. Mayor Pete Buttigieg, seemed to directly impact former Vice President Joe Biden's performance in Iowa. And now an insurgent Klobuchar seems to have bit into the support of both Biden, Buttigieg and other centrist rivals, not only to her own benefit, but to the boon of Sen. Bernie Sanders, who claimed an overwhelming victory over a divided field in New Hampshire.

While most other states vote by precinct, New Hamphire votes by town, and breaking the results down to that level reveals where Klobuchar performed best, often to the detriment of Biden and Buttigieg.

A split centrist vote helped progressives

Sanders' win in New Hampshire, while not as overwhelming as his 2016 primary victory, was partially made possible by a fractured bloc of center-left voters who split their support between Buttigieg, Biden and Klobuchar.

Slicing the race into progressive and centrist blocs of the top-finishing candidates shows New Hampshire voters overall preferred Klobuchar, Buttigieg and Biden over progressive firebrands like Sanders or Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren by a significant margin.

Klobuchar's small-town appeal

New Hampshire – a predominantly white, rural swing state dotted with small towns – is the sort of place Klobuchar has argued she could reach due to her strong support at home in Greater Minnesota.

Results from this primary seemingly lends some credance to that argument, as her small-town performance was strong across the board, not just in tiny Dixville Notch, but Concord, Nashua and Derry.

Klobuchar also had some of her strongest Iowa support in areas surrounding college towns, and this trend continued in New Hampshire. While Sanders dominated the campuses themselves, the ring of surrounding towns often leaned in Klobuchar's direction.

The road through Super Tuesday

In the next couple weeks, Nevada will hold its caucuses, followed by South Carolina's primaries, the final two contests before Super Tuesday on March 3, where Minnesota and about a third of delegates are up for grabs.

Klobuchar's polling has mostly been in the field's lower tier, according to Real Clear Politics averages. Though these states are polled more heavily in coming weeks, Klobuchar may see further bumps in support.

Jeff Hargarten is a data journalist for the Star Tribune focusing on data-driven reporting and visualization. He has covered elections, technology, criminal justice, demographics and public health.
